rename.to: [DOC] Add multivariate forecasting examples to forecasting tutorial

body:
No, currently not - good point! This should be added.

I think it's a good first issue?

issue.title: [DOC] Feedback thread on tutorial notebooks

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body:
This issue is for collecting feedback on the tutorial notebooks.

Any feedback is highly appreciated, positive or critical; can be high-level (e.g., too long where, helpful why, confusing how), or concrete, e.g., content that should be added, changed, removed, shortened, structured differently, etc.

issue.title: Adding vector forecasting API + examples

labels.name: implementing framework
labels.description: Implementing frameworks for new learning tasks

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body:
Hello sktimers

**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**
Currently it seems there is no native solution to, given a sliding window N x T, make predictions that at each time step provide N values (vector forecasting). At least I could not find it.

**Describe the solution you'd like**
I think we could include a native way to work with models that allow input matrices and output vectors.

**Describe alternatives you've considered**
A possible ``hack`` could be to have a single regressor for each of features in the multidimensional timeseries and join the outputs. Nevertheless, this does not take into account any correlation between the different input feature and output features.

I am willing to help, and moreover, we could try to think for a high level abstraction that could also be applied to MLJTime.

issue.title: [DOC] improvements to the forecasting tutorial

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body:
#### Reference Issues/PRs
None yet, just fixing typos in `docs/source/examples/01_forecasting.ipynb`. Likely will end up fixing #1446.

#### What does this implement/fix? Explain your changes.
Fixed typos, but before proceeding further I would like to clarify one thing about subsection `1.4 advanced deployment workflow: rolling updates & forecasts`. Just to make sure, does `update` re-fit the estimator? If so, I would make it clearer.

body: @kejsitake has expressed interest - assigned to track interest, revisit later.

issue.title: [DOC] forecaster tutorial: multivariate forecasting, probabilistic forecasting

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body:
<!--

at our contribution guide: https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/blob/main/CONTRIBUTING.md
-->

#### Reference Issues/PRs
<!--
Example: Fixes #1234. See also #3456.

Please use keywords (e.g., Fixes) to create link to the issues or pull requests
you resolved, so that they will automatically be closed when your pull request
is merged. See https://github.com/blog/1506-closing-issues-via-pull-requests
-->
Attempt to fix https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/issues/1985 and https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/issues/1446

#### What does this implement/fix? Explain your changes.
<!--
A clear and concise description of what you have implemented.
-->

This PR adds an explanation of the new `predict_quantiles` interface to the forecasting tutorial. It also adds a multivariate example as requested in issue https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/issues/1447
